11. Investment Program Summary
The impact of the proposed investment program will ensure future growth in the greater Suva area (GSA) is sustainable and will 
improve public health. The outcome will be improved access to sustainable water supply and sewerage services in the GSA.  
The investment program has three outputs:
Output 1: Supply and access to safe water in the GSA improved. The investment will expand water supply by 40,000 m3 per 
day by constructing a new supply intake on the Rewa river with associated water treatment plant, pumping station, reservoir, 
and transmission main to connect to the existing system. Reliable and sustainable long term operations and maintenance 
practices will be enhanced through a Design-Build-Operate (DBO) contracting arrangement. A catchment management plan will 
be developed to safeguard the water source and ensure long term sustainability. Non-revenue water (NRW) reduction will be 
achieved by improving leak detection and repairs; replacing meters; and establishing district metering areas and pressure 
management systems. Water Authority of Fiji (WAF) will supply 200 liters per capital per day to 315,947 persons by 2023, 
ensuring continuous supply to 98% of the GSA population. The climate change component of Output 1 will include adaptation 
measures for building the new Rewa river scheme specifically moving the facility from 29 km to 49 km from the river mouth to 
avoid future climate change impacts embodied in projected rising sea levels and potential migration of the salt water wedge up 
the river.
Output 2: Wastewater treatment (WWT) and management capacity in the GSA increased. The wastewater network will be 
rehabilitated and expanded by: (i) upgrading 31 existing wastewater pumping stations; (ii) upgrading about 18 km of wastewater 
trunk mains to increase carrying capacity; (iii) relining 13 km of wastewater trunk mains; and (iv) extending the wastewater 
network to service an additional 15% of households (approximately 4,500 existing lots in backlog areas) currently using septic 
tanks. Additionally, the WWT capacity at Kinoya will be expanded by 164% to cover approximately 277,000 person equivalent to
treat wastewater from current and future households. By improving the network and expanding the WWT capacity, WAF will 
ensure that 60% of households in the GSA will have access to a reticulated sewage collection system by 2023. The remaining 
households with individual septic units will be catered by a fecal sludge management system.
Output 3: WAF management and sustainable service delivery capacity improved. Program management and capacity 
development support will be provided to: (i) support WAF in the implementation of water demand management, NRW reduction 
and the national liquid trade waste management programs;  (ii) support the Department of Environment (DOE) developing the 
environmental regulatory framework for treated municipal wastewater discharge, sludge treatment and disposal practices and 
standards, and associated monitoring and enforcement; (iii) complete the corporatization of WAF; (iv) formulate water safety 
plans to protect the quantity and quality of water at all source intakes;  (v) improve financial management; (vi) promote gender 
equity; and (vii) study alternatives to reduce the long term energy consumption of the existing urban WWT system.
Impact: The impact will be sustainable urban growth and improved public health in the greater Suva area. 
Outcome: Access to sustainable water supply and sewerage services in GSA improved 
Outputs: (i)Supply and access to safe water in the GSA improved, (ii)Wastewater treatment and management capacity in the 
GSA increased,  and (iii)WAF management and sustainable service delivery capacity improved
Implementation Arrangements: Ministry of Economy will be the executing agency.
 
Project Readiness: Project Design Advance for Consultancy Packages have been contracted.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the Republic of Fiji for the Urban Water Supply and 
Wastewater Management Investment Program.1 
 
2.  The investment program will augment vital urban infrastructure and services to support 
sustainable growth and development in the greater Suva area (GSA) in and around Fiji’s capital 
city.  It  will  (i)  increase the  capacity  of  the GSA’s  water  supply  and  wastewater  treatment 
systems, and (ii) help the state-owned Water Authority of Fiji (WAF) improve its operational 
efficiency and the quality of its services by reducing losses due to nonrevenue water (NRW) and 
improving the management of water demand and liquid trade waste.2 The investment program 
will also support the government’s development and implementation of water and sewerage 
policy  and  regulatory  reforms.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  provided  technical 
assistance  and  a  project  design  advance  loan  ($2.65  million)  to  prepare  the  investment 
program.3 
 
II.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Background and sector issues. Fiji’s population was estimated to be 893,000 in 2015, 
up from 837,200 in the last census in 2007.4 About 54% of its people live in urban areas, and 
this is projected to increase to 61% by 2030. About 57% of these urban dwellers, or about 
275,000 people, are concentrated in the GSA. Many live in the area’s informal settlements 
without access to essential services. The GSA accounts for 40% of Fiji’s gross domestic product, 
which makes solving its urban development issues critical to the country’s economic future. The 
government  has  increased  public  spending  to  improve  basic  services  and  address  the 
challenges and unlock the economic potential of the area’s largely unplanned rapid growth. 
Government resources are limited, however, investment in almost all public services has fallen 
short of needs, including those for improved urban water supply and wastewater.  
 
4.  Constraints on water supply. The WAF’s water supply network covered an estimated 
95% of the GSA’s urban population in 2014, but services are intermittent in some communities 
and face several constraints. The Waila and Tamavua water treatment plants serve the GSA, 
with a combined average production capacity of about 150,000 cubic meters (m3) per day. Both 
plants are operating at full capacity but cannot meet the current peak demand. This also means 
that the WAF cannot expand its supply network to peri-urban or new growth areas. 
 
5.  The Waimanu River is currently the only source of raw water for treatment and supply, 
and it cannot fully meet the system’s needs during extended droughts when its water level drops. 
Service interruptions occur not only during dry periods, but also during heavy rains when 
increased turbidity requires more frequent backwashing of the water treatment plant filters.

These interruptions and the overall reliability of the water supply in the GSA will be further 
compromised by such forecast climate change impacts and more extreme weather events.  
 
6.  The supply shortages are exacerbated by the WAF’s high rate of NRW losses, although 
these have declined, through the utility’s significant efforts, from 51.0% in 2014 to 39.2% in 
2016.5 The WAF aims to reduce the NRW rate to 27% by 2033, which will require an increased 
focus on detecting leaks, replacement of aging pipelines, and routine maintenance.  
  
7.  Wastewater management. Public health risks in the GSA and pollution in local creeks 
and waterways have increased due to overflows from the WAF sewerage system, the discharge 
of trade and industry waste into storm water drains, and seepage from domestic sanitation 
systems.  In  2013,  only  36%  of  the  GSA’s  urban  population  was  covered  by  its  existing 
sewerage  infrastructure.6 The  Kinoya  wastewater  treatment—the  GSA’s  main  wastewater 
treatment facility—is working beyond its current rated capacity. Because of this, its final effluent 
does not meet regulatory standards. The plant needs hydraulic and treatment process upgrades 
if it is to properly treat current and projected wastewater flows. Insufficient investment in proper 
maintenance  of  wastewater  treatment  and  sewerage  infrastructure  has  led  to  widespread 
deterioration of these assets. The pump stations and pipelines need rehabilitation and capacity 
upgrades before any more connections can be made to the system.  
 
8.  Institutional  framework.  The  government  assigned  the  functions  and  operational 
responsibilities of its water and sewerage department to the WAF in 2007 and made it a 
commercial  statutory  authority  in  2010.7 The WAF  has  invested  in  capital  and  operational 
improvements  aimed  at  providing  an  effective  water  supply  and  wastewater  system  and 
services in the GSA even though the government has not enabled it to become financially 
autonomous, or allowed tariff adjustments to improve cost recovery. WAF revenue from tariffs in 
FY2014 totaled $14.7 million. With earnings of $8.4 million from other sources, its overall 
income was $23.1 million. Its operational and maintenance costs, excluding depreciation, were 
$36  million.  The  WAF’s  costs  rose  by  14%  during  2010–2014.8 Although  the  WAF  has 
requested increases, domestic water tariffs have not changed in Fiji since a value-added tax 
was  removed  in  1999.  Tariff  revenues  go  into  the  government’s  consolidated  fund.  The 
government  provides  annual  grant  subsidies  meant  to  cover  the  WAF’s  operational, 
maintenance, and capital expenses.  
 
9.  The  main  obstacles  to  the  WAF’s  financial  sustainability  are  low  tariffs  and  the 
requirement that it remit all tariff revenue to the Ministry of Economy (MOE) (footnote 8). The 
proposed investment program will support WAF to be more financially sustainable and more 
accountable to regulatory bodies by (i) helping it to improve its financial management systems, 
(ii) requiring the government to review and reform water and sewerage tariffs, and (iii) providing 
for a review of regulations that affect how water resources and wastewater are managed. 
 
10.  Policy  framework,  sector  road  map,  and  investment  plan.  The  draft  of  the 
government’s  new  national  development  plan  (NDP) for  2016–20369 focuses  on  achieving 
inclusive and sustainable development and meeting basic needs. The NDP makes the provision

of safe drinking water and basic sanitation to every household as well as improving service 
delivery national priorities through public sector reforms and regulation. Policy reforms include 
completing the WAF corporatization process to improve WAF’s financial autonomy, operations 
and service delivery which is required under both the WAF Promulgation 2007, and under the 
Public Enterprise Act 1996. There has been ongoing technical assistance and dialogue to help 
WAF in this regard and is a feature of the proposed MFF. Other sector improvements planned 
include the formulation of national water and sanitation policy, water catchment management 
plans, and reviews of the environmental regulatory framework. A key regulatory action will 
include the municipal wastewater discharge standards to be reviewed and strengthened under 
the Environment Management Act 2005. 
  
11.  The NDP provides a road map, strategic context, policy framework, and a medium-term 
sector development plan (SDP) 2016–2021, for water supply and sanitation (WSS). The SDP’s 
objectives  cover  technical  sustainability;  environmental  and  integrated  water  resource 
management; and improvements in sector policy, legislative, and regulatory frameworks.10 The 
NDP’s long-term target for 2035 is for 100% of the population to have access to piped and safe 
drinking water, and 70% to have access to a central sewerage system. The SDP target for 2021 
is access to piped and safe drinking water for 100% of the country’s urban population and 
access to a central sewerage system for 40% of urban residents. The SDP adopts an inclusive 
development approach that targets the urban poor, particularly those living in (i) peri-urban 
squatter settlements that have limited access to water and sewerage services, (ii) existing 
suburban  residential  areas  not  currently  serviced,  and  (iii)  new  growth  areas.  The  annual 
financing requirements for the SDP exceed all previous annual budget provisions. The SDP 
objectives are consistent with ADB’s water operational plan for 2011–2020 and ADB’s water 
policy.11 The overall sector strategy is supported by a WAF water and wastewater master plan 
for the GSA covering 2013–2033 (footnote 6). 
 
12.  Strategic context. The proposed investment program is aligned with ADB’s country 
partnership strategy for Fiji for 2014–2018, which aims to improve municipal services in the 
country by continuing to upgrade urban WSS systems, introducing utility tariffs that cover the 
costs of service delivery, and improving environmental infrastructure. ADB has been a long-
standing partner in government and WAF efforts to implement WSS reforms and improve urban 
WSS infrastructure.12 The proposed MFF is included in ADB’s country operations business plan 
for 2017–2019 and is consistent with ADB’s objective to enter into a long-term partnership with 
Fiji to support the country’s growth potential, particularly by strengthening WSS services.13  
 
13.  Use  of  the  multitranche  financing  facility.  Use  of  ADB’s  MFF  modality  for  the 
investment program provides three advantages for ADB and the government. It will help achieve 
ADB’s objective under its country operations business plan to establish a long-term partnership 
with  Fiji  to  enhance  WSS  services.  It  will  help  the  government  manage  its  development 
financing efficiently. It will improve the government’s capacity to meet the required development

financing envelope for the proposed water and sanitation program outlined in the SDP.14 The 
investment program will involve a priority water supply project under tranche 1 and a priority 
wastewater project under tranche 2. They are to be sequenced based on (i) project readiness, 
(ii) the introduction of reforms, and (iii) the WAF’s demonstrated absorptive capacity to operate 
and maintain the new systems. WAF has increased its project staff to support the investment 
program implementation; this coupled with the support from the PDA consultants, will mitigate 
governance and capacity risks. The required MFF requirements—i.e., a sector road map, an 
investment program, strategic context, and a policy framework—are in place. The MFF modality 
will give the government ongoing support for medium- and long-term investment planning. It 
allows  ADB  to  align financing  with  project  readiness  and sector  reforms. The government 
requested an MFF because of its flexibility and the ability it affords to finance investments 
sequentially as each project becomes ready for implementation and will contribute 37% of the 
overall investment program financing. 
 
14.  Development partner coordination. ADB has been engaged in Fiji’s WSS sector since 
1998 and takes a lead role in coordinating development partner planning and activities. Past 
sector  lessons  demonstrate  that  the  sector’s  physical  investment requirements  exceed  the 
financing available from any single development institution. They also show a need for capacity 
building and the importance of strong leadership by the government and WAF. While preparing 
the proposed investment program, ADB helped the government successfully apply for grant 
financing of $31 million to the Green Climate Fund (GCF) and collaborates with the European 
Investment Bank, which is committed to cofinancing the investment program.  
B.  Impact and Outcome 
15.  The impact will be sustainable urban growth and improved public health in the GSA. The 
outcome will be improved access to sustainable water supply and sewerage services in the 
GSA.    
 
C.  Outputs 
 
16.  Output 1: Supply of and access to safe water in the greater Suva area improved. 
Project 1 of the investment program will increase water supply to the GSA by 40,000 m3 per day 
by constructing a new supply intake on the Rewa River, an associated water treatment plant, a 
pumping station, a reservoir, and a transmission main to connect the new water supply to the 
WAF’s existing distribution system. To enhance climate resilience, the planned location of the 
new Rewa River scheme is located 49 kilometers (km) from the river’s mouth to avoid the 
potential future impacts of rising sea levels that are likely to push saltwater further up the river. 
Reliable, long-term operation and maintenance will be provided through a design–build–operate 
contracting arrangement. A water safety plan and water catchment management plan will be 
developed to safeguard the water source and ensure long-term sustainability. Leak detection 
will be improved, repairs undertaken, water meters replaced, and district metering areas and 
pressure management systems established in WAF’s existing distribution network to reduce the 
current high level of NRW down to 36% by 2022. During implementation of the investment 
program, WAF will be able to expand network coverage and provide 98% of GSA’s population 
with a continuous supply of safe water by 2023.

17.  Output 2: Wastewater treatment and management capacity in the greater Suva 
area increased. Project 2 of the investment program will be to rehabilitate and expand the 
sewerage network by (i) upgrading 31 existing wastewater pumping stations, (ii) upgrading 
about 18 km of sewer trunk mains to increase carrying capacity, (iii) rehabilitating 13 km of 
sewer trunk mains, and (iv) extending the sewerage network to service an additional 4,500 
households currently using on-site septic tanks. The wastewater treatment capacity at Kinoya 
will be increased twofold, providing effective treatment of wastewater for up to 277,000 people 
in the GSA. By increasing wastewater treatment capacity and expanding the sewerage network, 
the WAF will ensure that 60% of households in the GSA have access to a reticulated sewerage 
system by 2023.   
 
18.  Output 3: Water Authority of Fiji management and sustainable service delivery 
capacity  improved.  Through  the  Projects  1  and  2,  the  investment  program  will  provide 
institutional capacity building and implementation support. This support will help the WAF carry 
out programs to manage water demand, reduce NRW, and manage liquid trade waste.15 It will 
help the Department of Environment develop an environmental framework for regulating treated 
municipal  wastewater  discharge  and  residual  sludge  treatment  and  disposal  practices  and 
standards,  along  with  associated  monitoring  and  enforcement  systems.  The  investment 
program will help the government carry out the corporatization of the WAF, improve WAF’s 
financial management, and promote gender equity.  
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
19.  The investment program is estimated to cost $405.1 million (Table 1). It will comprise 
two projects.16 Detailed designs for new infrastructure under both projects are at an advanced 
stage of preparation and expected to be final by June 2017.

21.  The government has requested an MFF in an amount of up to $184.2 million to help 
finance a part of the investment program. The MFF will consist of two tranches, subject to the 
government's submission of related periodic financing requests, execution of the related legal 
agreements for each tranche, and fulfillment of terms and conditions and undertakings set forth 
in the framework financing agreement. The MFF amount will be converted into loans from 
ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources  (OCR)  and  grant  cofinancing  from  the  GCF.  Tranche  1 
includes a total investment of $73,149,000, comprising (i) a loan of $42,109,000 from OCR, with 
a 21-year term, including a grace period of 6 years, an annual interest rate determined in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  London  interbank  offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a 
commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms and conditions set forth in the loan 
and project agreements;17 and (ii) grant cofinancing from the GCF equivalent to $31,040,000, to 
be administered by ADB (subject to negotiation).18 Tranche proceeds will be included in the 
government’s budgetary transfers to the WAF. The remainder of the financing for project 1 will 
comprise (i) a loan from the European Investment Bank of $26.6 million,19 which will not be 
administered by ADB; and (ii) a government contribution of $80.7 million for project costs, 
including taxes, duties, land acquisition, and operation and maintenance costs included in the

A.  Technical

have determined that the proposed designs of the centralized water and sewerage network to

the project design advance loan, consultants have been recruited to (i) finalize the detailed

Procurement will be initiated in July 2017. Project 1 will include a design–build–operate contract

of the new Rewa River scheme provides additional security against salt water intrusion impacts 
that are likely due to climate change and rising sea levels. Project 1 will support the detailed 
engineering, due diligence, and advance contracting for the physical wastewater treatment and 
sewerage system upgrades required for output 2 and scheduled under project 2.22 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
24.  Preliminary economic analysis indicated that the overall investment program has an 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 8.3%. The analysis noted that the investment program 
has significant health and environmental benefits that should be considered as overall economic 
benefits but were not quantified for calculating the EIRR. With this in mind, the program is 
considered to have sufficient economic merit despite the EIRR being below the 12% threshold.  
The EIRR for project 1 is 8.5%. Project 1 will increase water supply in the GSA, thereby 
improving the WAF’s service to existing customers and helping to accommodate population 
growth in the area. Project 1 will reduce the WAF’s high levels of NRW, making more water 
available at a relatively low cost. The project will prevent a gradual erosion of the current 
system’s capacity due to lack of redundancy for maintenance. Preliminary calculations for the 
wastewater investments indicate an EIRR for project 2 of 7.7%. An expanded sewerage system 
will eliminate costs now incurred by those still to be connected by displacing such wastewater 
disposal systems as septic tanks. The project will allow higher density development in new 
areas to be served. A financial analysis prepared in accordance with ADB guidelines calculated 
a negative financial internal rate of return for project 1 based on the assumption that the WAF’s 
current water tariffs will not increase.23 The current weighted water tariff of F$0.46 per m3 covers 
only about half of the average incremental financial cost of the WAF water supply of F$0.94 per 
m3. To achieve an operating ratio of less than 1, project 1 will ensure (i) that tariff adjustments 
are made on the principle of cost recovery, and (ii) that the government makes funding available 
to fill the cost-recovery gap.  
 
C.  Governance 
25.  An  assessment  conducted  by  ADB  of  the  WAF’s  and  the  government’s  financial 
management found no major country-level issues. Fiji has an effective, well-functioning public 
sector. The overall inherent risk was assessed as low, but the overall control risk was assessed 
as substantial. This is due to (i) the WAF’s lack of financial autonomy, (ii) problematic findings 
from  the WAF’s  external  audits,  (iii)  weak  information  systems,  and  (iv)  inadequate WAF 
reporting. The investment program will address the control risk through long-term WAF financial 
management capacity building. It will support the corporatization of the WAF and help it develop 
a strategy to become financially sustainable within the investment program period to improve its 
financial autonomy and service delivery.

D.  Poverty and Social 
 
26.  Inadequate  water  and  sanitation  services  currently  compromise  public  health  and 
constrain economic development in Fiji. Poverty incidence in informal urban settlements has 
been estimated at 53%, and the lack of access to urban services has a particularly large 
negative impact on women and children.24 The investment program will help reduce poverty by 
improving the  water  supply  available  for the  connection  of  services  and  sewerage  will  be 
extended, providing increased access to settlements and new growth areas in the GSA. Project 
1 is classified effective gender mainstreaming.25 Execution of the gender action plan will help 
give women better access to services and strengthen the WAF’s institutional capacity to ensure 
long-term sustainable gender mainstreaming.  
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
27.  Environment. Project 1 is classified category B for the environment. The environmental 
assessment review framework for the investment program and a draft initial environmental 
examination for project 1 have been prepared. The initial environmental examination including 
the environment management plan is considered to be sufficient to meet environmental the 
requirements. Project 2 is expected to be classified categorization of B or C for the environment. 
 
28.  Involuntary resettlement. Project 1 is classified category B for involuntary resettlement. 
The resettlement framework for the investment program and a draft resettlement plan have 
been prepared for project 1. Land must be acquired by the government and the WAF. The 
affected persons have been identified in the resettlement plan, which will be updated after 
detailed  design.  Project  2  is  expected  to  be  classified  category  B  or  C  for  involuntary 
resettlement. 
 
29.  Indigenous peoples. Project 1 is classified category C for the indigenous peoples. No 
impacts are expected under project 1 on distinct and vulnerable groups of indigenous peoples 
as defined under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). A planning framework for possible 
impacts  on  indigenous  peoples  was  prepared  to  meet  mandatory  MFF  requirements  and 
address any unanticipated issues that could arise under project 2.

IV.  ASSURANCES 
31.  The government and WAF have assured ADB that implementation of the investment 
program shall conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption 
measures,  safeguards,  gender,  procurement,  consulting  services,  and  disbursement  as 
described in detail in the FAM and project 1 loan and project agreements (and as will be 
described in the grant agreement). 27  
 
32.  The government and WAF have given ADB certain undertakings for the MFF, which are 
set forth in the framework financing agreement. Specific covenants agreed by the government 
and WAF with respect to project 1 are set forth in the loan and project agreements (and will be 
set forth in the grant agreement). 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
33.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the multitranche financing facility to the Republic of Fiji for the Urban Water Supply and 
Wastewater Management Investment Program in an aggregate principal amount not exceeding 
the equivalent of $184,240,000, which comprises: 
 
(i)  the provision of loans from ADB's ordinary capital resources, with interest and other 
terms to be determined in accordance with ADB's London interbank offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility; and  
(ii) the administration of cofinancing (subject to negotiation) to be provided by the Green 
Climate Fund and any other development partner; 
 
and is subject to such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in the framework financing agreement presented to the Board.

Appendix 1  13 
Key Activities with Milestones  
1.  Supply and access to safe water in the GSA improved 
1.1  Design and build a new water intake in the Rewa River, an associated water treatment plant, a pumping station, 
and a reservoir to increase production by 40,000 m3 per day.  
1.2  Implement a meter replacement program. 
1.3  Implement a program to improve leak detection and repairs by the WAF. 
1.4  Establish district metering areas and pressure management systems in GSA. 
1.5  Improve customer databases and billing systems. 
1.6  Implement upgrading works recommendations from asset condition assessment undertaken for all water pipes 
greater than 15 cm within the GSA. 
2.  Wastewater treatment and management capacity in the GSA increased 
2.1  Increase wastewater treatment capacity of Kinoya WTP to about a 277,000 person equivalent rating by designing 
and building new treatment facilities—two primary sedimentation tanks and a new digester—and upgrading the 
dewatering plant. 
2.2  Install technology to enable future beneficial re-use of methane gas for energy at the Kinoya WTP. 
2.3  Upgrade 31 existing wastewater pumping stations to allow more flow to the treatment plant. 
2.4  Replace 8 km of wastewater trunk mains and reline 13 km of wastewater trunk mains that are reaching the end of 
their asset life. 
2.5  Design and build new wastewater infrastructure to service an additional 15% of the households in 4,500 lots in 
backlog areas and in new development areas (2,000 new lots). 
3.  WAF management and sustainable service delivery capacity improved  
3.1  Develop and implement a water demand management program. 
3.2  Train WAF personnel on leak detection and reduction of NRW.  
3.3  Develop and implement a strategy for the WAF to monitor and enforce the national liquid trade waste program. 
3.4  Carry out WAF’s corporatization activities, including transfer of assets, governance arrangements, improvement of 
financial sustainability, and the retention of revenue.  
3.5  Develop water catchment management plans and water safety plans to protect the quantity and quality of the water 
at the intakes for all the water sources in the investment program area.  
3.6  Review WAF financial management practices and policies and develop a strategy to address recommendations to 
improve the WAF’s financial reporting and management. 
3.7  Promote gender equity in the WAF’s business practices by providing training and reviewing policies.
